title: LCZ4r Local Functions
text: lcz_ts() function, can analyze air temperature associated LCZ classes time. instance, can perform hourly frequency analysis air temperature years 2019-2020 using “lcz_data” LCZ4r package.  Additionally, can customize function: 1. Flexibility time selection flexibility select specific years months analysis. example, can specify range years (e.g., 1998:2004) individual years (e.g., c(1998, 2004)). Similarly, can select months either numerically (e.g., 1:6 January June) name (e.g., c(“January”, “December”)). illustrate, can select data September 1st, 2019, including arguments “year”, “month”, “day” function call. See utility functions openair package details.  2. Splitting LCZ time series temporal window site can split data frame calling argument. split available “year”, “season”, “seasonyear”, “month”, “monthyear”, “weekday”, “weekend”, “daylight” (daytime nighttime). See argument type openair package:
code: # Get the LCZ map for your city lcz_map <- lcz_get_map(city="Berlin") #> Congratulations! You've successfully got Berlin LCZ map.  #Let's get LCZ air temperature time series lcz_ts(lcz_map, data_frame = lcz_data,         var = "airT", station_id = "station",        time.freq = "month") # Monthly temporal frequency. Let's change to "hour, "day", "week", and so on. #> Congrats! You've successfully performed a month time series based on LCZ classes. #Selecting one specifique day lcz_ts(lcz_map, data_frame = lcz_data,         var = "airT", station_id = "station",        time.freq = "hour",         year = 2019, month = 9, day = 1) #> Congrats! You've successfully performed a hour time series based on LCZ classes. #Splitting by daylight  lcz_ts(lcz_map, data_frame = lcz_data,         var = "airT", station_id = "station",        time.freq = "hour", # frequency changed to hour        year = 2019, month = 9, day = 1, by = "daylight")  #> Congrats! You've successfully performed a hour time series by daylight based on LCZ classes.

title: LCZ4r Local Functions
text: thermal anomaly great way evaluate intra-urban air temperatures differences. LCZ station, thermal anomaly defined difference temperature overall mean temperature LCZ stations. instance, positive temperature anomaly indicates particular LCZ warmer compared LCZs. lcz_anomaly() function utilities lcz_ts() regarding Flexibility time selection Splitting LCZ time series temporal window site.
code: # If you want the thermal anomalies 1 sept 2020 on hourly basis. lcz_anomaly(lcz_map, data_frame = lcz_data,              var = "airT", station_id = "station",              time.freq = "hour", #Let's change the frequency to "day", "month", "year"             year = 2020, month = 9, day = 1) #> You've successfully generated anomalies based on LCZ classes. # If you want the thermal anomalies by months of 2020 on daily basis. lcz_anomaly(lcz_map, data_frame = lcz_data,              var = "airT", station_id = "station",              time.freq = "day", #Let's change the frequency to "day", "month", "year"             year = 2020, by = "month") #> You've successfully generated anomalies by month based on LCZ classes.

title: LCZ4r Local Functions
text: ’re still us everything running rightly, can proceed generate map LCZ thermal anomalies using lcz_anomaly_map() function. function employs interpolation techniques Kriging IDW calculate interpolate anomalies. settings time frequency data splitting, utilized lcz_ts lcz_anomaly() functions, remain relatively unchanged. , two new arguments consider: sp.res (spatial resolution map meters) tp.res (frequency values averaged). lcz_anomaly_map function returns either single raster file stack raster files. Subsequently, can visualize anomaly map using lcz_plot_interp() function.
code: #Mapping anomalies for 1st Sep 2020 at 09:00h using kriging my_anomaly_map <- lcz_anomaly_map(lcz_map,                                 data_frame = lcz_data, var = "airT", station_id = "station",                                 sp.res = 100, tp.res = "hour",                                 year = 2020, month = 9, day = 1, hour = 9,                                 method = "kriging") #> [ordinary or weighted least squares prediction] #> That's cool! Let's explore your LCZ anomaly map.  #Plot anomaly map. Note that the argument ... is used to title etc.. lcz_plot_interp(my_anomaly_map,                  title = "LCZ-thermal anomalies",                  subtitle = "Berlin - 01.09.2020 at 09:00",                 caption = "Source: LCZ4r, 2024.",                 fill = "[ºC]") # Active the by argument! Mapping daytime and nighttime anomalies for 1st Sep 2020 my_anomlay_daylight <- lcz_anomaly_map(lcz_map,                               data_frame = lcz_data, var = "airT", station_id = "station",                               sp.res = 100, tp.res = "hour",                               year = 2020, month = 9, day = 1,                               by="daylight",                               method = "kriging") #> [ordinary or weighted least squares prediction] #> [ordinary or weighted least squares prediction] #> That's cool! Let's explore your LCZ anomaly map.  my_anomlay_daylight #> class       : SpatRaster  #> dimensions  : 617, 749, 2  (nrow, ncol, nlyr) #> resolution  : 100, 100  (x, y) #> extent      : 1457000, 1531900, 6861482, 6923182  (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax) #> coord. ref. : WGS 84 / Pseudo-Mercator (EPSG:3857)  #> source(s)   : memory #> names       : krige_20200901050000_daylight, krige_20200901_nighttime  #> min values  :                    -0.9652088,                -2.344815  #> max values  :                     0.7134152,                 1.733124  #Plot anomaly map. Note that I renamed the raster layers names(my_anomlay_daylight) <- c("daytime", "nighttime")  lcz_plot_interp(my_anomlay_daylight,                  title = "LCZ-thermal anomalies",                  subtitle = "Berlin - daytime and nighttime (01.09.2020)",                 caption = "Source: LCZ4r, 2024.",                 fill = "[ºC]")
